newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: No avalanche of labour laws - Santer.
newsitem.headline: No avalanche of labour laws - Santer.

text.p: There will be no new wave of labour rules imposed on European Union employers as a result of Britain's decision to adopt the EU Social Chapter, European Commission President Jacques Santer said on Friday.
"We have absolutely no intention of launching an avalanche," Santer's spokesman, Nikolaus van der Pas, quoted him as telling new British Prime Minister Tony Blair.

Blair, meeting the EU executive's leader on the margins of a summit, repeated his government's decision to sign up to the Social Chapter, an agreement designed to set standards of worker protection across the bloc.

The former Conservative government had negotiated an opt-out from the laws, fearing that they would harm the competitiveness of British industry. Critics charged that it left Britons with fewer workplace rights than their EU colleagues.
But Blair warned Santer that although he would now adopt the EU labour laws there was much concern in Britain that Brussels would unleash a tide of new rules.
A British aide said Blair told Santer there would be "serious political difficulties in the United Kingdom if the UK signing of the Social Chapter led to a flood of proposals for social regulation."
He also called for flexibility in the labour market.
Van der Pas said Santer had emphasised to Blair that the Social Chapter was designed to provide minimum protections to workers and that there would be no flood unleashed.
